alert.note: Alert for Cumberland (Maine) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 30 at 11:15PM EDT until May 02 at 7:00AM EDT by NWS Gray/Portland
info.description: ...Forecast flooding changed from Minor to Moderate severity and increased in duration for the following rivers in Maine... Presumpscot River At West Falmouth affecting Cumberland County. For the Presumpscot River...including West Falmouth...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM LATE TONIGHT TO TUESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Presumpscot River at West Falmouth. * WHEN...From late tonight to Tuesday morning. * IMPACTS...At 12.5 feet, River comes out of its banks and floods portions of Fraser Field. High flows make recreational activities hazardous. At 14.0 feet, Water approaches the backyards of properties along Water Street in Westbrook and Riverside Street in Portland. At 15.0 feet, Minor flooding affects storage yards of industrial businesses on Warren Avenue in Westbrook. Property should be relocated to places which are 5 feet higher than nearby river banks to avoid being flooded or isolated. At 16.0 feet, Minor flooding with water encroaching upon East Bridge Street in Westbrook and Route 302. Riverbank Park in Westbrook floods. Sappi Wastewater Drive access cut off by floodwaters. At 21.0 feet, Flooding along Route 302 and East Bridge Street in Westbrook. Water Street flooded near Mentor Street with residential properties impacted. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 10:30 PM EDT Sunday the stage was 8.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage late tonight to a crest of 21.2 feet early tomorrow afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage early Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Please report observed flooding to local emergency services or law enforcement and request they pass this information to the National Weather Service when you can do so safely. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/gray.
